17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - cereal, oatmeal, cornmeal, or cracked wheat; soft-boiled eggs, cheese melted, jam, toast, dried apple sauce, or honey, coffee or milk.

Dinner - roast beef, boiled ham, dumplings, potatoes, baked onion, carrots, onions.

Supper - soup, bean-vegetable, or tomato-milk, pancakes, syrup (homemade often), bread, biscuits, or cake, jam.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1900

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Beef, roast chicken, dressing, mashed potatoes, turnips, onions.

Carrot pudding, recipe from both sides of the house, was back!

Spice sauce.

We two: J.R.E.A. Stouden - 30 yrs.

Son, Calvin Washington - 14 yrs.

My brother Dr. E. Day, Washington, Weyburn, Sask.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No, but we would have been in 1900+ if my father, Rev. W.C. Washington, Barrie But. had not borrowed $300 (on his character) from a bank, loaned it to us for about 3 years!

No crop 1900, arrived Weyburn too late.

Drought 1901.

Fair crop 1902, harvest in fall!

17. Give a typical daily menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast—Bacon, toast, scrambled eggs, potatoes (boiled or fried), carrots, beans, or honey, milk or cream, coffee or tea.

Dinner—Beefsteak, potatoes, peas, carrots, turnips, cabbage, onions.

Supper—Cheese, bread, tea.

We moved in to me for about 3 years.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Ethel Washington, Standon, Q.R. wife
Address: 1222 Pandora, Victoria, B.C., Canada
Birthplace: North Augusta (Quebec), daughter

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1900
Where did you set up housekeeping? Wayburn, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Old over Ontario-Barnes
For how many people did you prepare meals? 2 adults, 3 children
How far was it to your nearest store? 3.5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? On Sundays, sometimes Saturdays
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Soda, Citric acid, sugar, dried apples, golden syrup, flour, butter, sometimes spices, vinegar

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? "Flax of the Woods"
In what quantities did you buy it? 10 lb.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $1.50
How much did you use graham flour? Nearly as much as white
Whole wheat flour? No
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.50
What other grain products did you use? Wheat grits
Cornmeal? Yes
Whole Wheat? Yes
Farina? No
Other? Pearl Barley
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
